item.title: CV

Living a minimalism-driven and adventurous life, preferring flexibility and ability to move to new places or work remotely Mad R Skills tidyverse forecast caret rmarkdown Other rad skills SQL Power BI Data Visualization All things data Languages: Russian - native Ukrainian - native English - fluent French - elementary to intermediate Main Work Experience Manager, Business Intelligence & CRM Suddath | April 2017 - Present | Jacksonville, FL

item.title: When your data analysis is validated on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert
item.description: Originally published on Medium on Dec 13, 2017: Original post About a month ago, I wrote a little article about the MPAA rating system. I set up to find out if their lettering system does any justice to the actual content seen on the screen. Briefly speaking, it does, but with caveats. One of such caveats was the effect of profanity. What my quick and dirty data analysis showed was that profanity was the sure thing that could send a movie into an R category:

item.title: Create World Pixel Maps in R
item.description: Today, I’m going to show you how to make pixel maps in R. Why pixel maps? Because they look awesome! I was searching on the web for a while, but couldn’t find a good tutorial. Being stubborn as I am, I eventually figured out a way to get what I want. You know, if you torture your code enough, it might give you what you need. Setup First, of course, loading required packages.

item.title: Do MPAA movie ratings mean anything?
item.description: Intro Being a parent in modern days is lots of fun. Not only all of us are pretty much winging it, not having any idea what we’re doing (seriously, you need a license to do braids and nails, yet raising a human being a future member of society is a no-brainer, right?) — we are also constantly being watched and judged by other parents. When it comes to watching movies with our six-year-old son, we don’t have a strict set of rules.
